instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL: What is PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL? This is the voltage coming directly from the charger after going through a transistor. .
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H? PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H is the input voltage to the PP3V42_G3H buck converter circuit, it can be either charger voltage or battery voltage depending on what the system power source is. This often shorts to ground when one of the input capacitors dies. .
definitions.PBUS_G3H: What is PBUS_G3H? This is a typo of PPBUS_G3H When you see PBUS_G3H, assume they meant to type PPBUS_G3H.

threads.title: 820-000165 - Charger green comes, Fan doesn't go on.
threads.message:
Hi, the above board has following voltages.


<SIGNAL>PBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 8.6V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL>:  16.5 
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>: 4.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>: 5.1V

<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H</SIGNAL> 16.2 
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H</SIGNAL>  16.5

<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>. Fluctuations from 0 to 3 (moving fast and difficult to read min and max using multimeter)
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>:  5.36

<CHIP>U7090</CHIP> was replaced. Still  <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> value is about five. Resisters are not open in voltage divider. Any clue to go ahead?

threads.title: 820-000165 - Charger green comes, Fan doesn't go on.
threads.message:
Play with Ra/Rb.
Increasing <RESISTOR>R7096</RESISTOR> will decrease 3V42; same effect for lower <RESISTOR>R7095</RESISTOR>.
Lower <RESISTOR>R7096</RESISTOR> will increase 3V42; same effect increasing <RESISTOR>R7095</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: 820-000165 - Charger green comes, Fan doesn't go on.
threads.message: Is bad <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is the reason for  <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> changes?

threads.title: 820-000165 - Charger green comes, Fan doesn't go on.
threads.message: I will pull resisters and check whether they have original values.

threads.title: 820-000165 - Charger green comes, Fan doesn't go on.
threads.message: You cannot expect the SMC to work propely if gets so high power...

threads.title: 820-000165 - Charger green comes, Fan doesn't go on.
threads.message: You are right. replacing Ra and Rb solved all problems. :)
